summary: The John F. Kennedy Assassination Records Collection Act of 1992 mandated the release of government documents related to the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. Compliance with the Act involved extensive efforts by agencies like the CIA to review, declassify, and release records, while also addressing concerns about sensitive information and privacy. This included contacting former employees whose names appeared in the documents, offering them the opportunity to request postponement of release. The Assassination Records Review Board (ARRB) played a crucial role in overseeing the implementation of the Act, balancing transparency with the protection of national security interests and individual privacy, such as redacting Social Security numbers from HSCA staff payroll records.
significance: High - The John F. Kennedy Assassination Records Collection Act is a central piece of legislation governing the release of information related to a major historical event. The high document count (70) indicates its pervasive influence on the document collection.
merged_from_variants: John F. Kennedy Assassination Records Collection Act
